key_steps: Plan and coordinate with utility and trades
Run service raceways and pull conductors
Terminate service and feeder cables at gear
materials: Main switchboard/switchgear (4000A, 480Y/277V, e.g. Square D, Siemens)
Service conductors (multiple 500 MCM XHHW cables or bus duct)
Rigid metal conduits (4"–5" RMC/IMC for service entrance)
Grounding equipment (ground bus, bonding jumpers, ground rods)

NEC: 250.24 & 250.28 – Grounding electrode connection & main bonding jumper
408.3 – Switchboard arrangement & barriers for service sections
110.26 – Working clearance (3 ft min in front, etc.)
Chicago: 14E-2-230(A)(5) – High-rise: service in fire-rated electrical room near vault​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
14E-2-230 – Require metallic raceway for service conductors above grade​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
230.95 mod – GFPE required on busway feeders ≥1000A (any voltage)​:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Ch.3 Amendment – All wiring in conduit/metal raceway (typical Chicago practice)​:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

labor_units: 4 inch EMT conduit: ~16 labor-hours per 100 ft (NECA normal conditions)​:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Terminating 500 MCM cable: ~0.7 hrs per lug (average conditions)​:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Installing 4000A switchgear main section: ~30–40 hrs (crew total, est.)​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Bus duct installation: ~0.3–0.5 hrs per foot + per joint assembly (varies)
common_pitfalls: Improper torque on lugs (loose connections cause overheating)
Omitting bonding jumper between neutral and ground at service​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Insufficient working clearance or egress in electrical room (NEC 110.26)
Foreign piping/sprinklers over gear without protection (water damage risk)
Mislabeling or phasing errors on parallel feeds (phase rotation issues)
trade_coordination: Utility: Schedule ComEd vault/meter installation and energization
Structural: Verify floor can support gear weight; install housekeeping pad
HVAC: Provide ventilation or cooling for electrical room (heat dissipation)
Plumbing: Keep water lines/sprinklers out of or shielded in electrical room
Fire Protection: Coordinate required room fire rating and any sprinkler exceptions
General Contractor: Path for bringing in large equipment (door removal, cranes)
